page.title: Basic Sentences - Conditionals
page.introduction: Conditionals have two parts: a condition and a consequence. The condition is introduced by a conditional word, such as if, when or after, and is set off by a comma. The consequence may be marked by a word meaning then in examples with the condition first. English examples include:

EnglishExample.exItem: If you save enough money, then you can buy that.
After you clean your room, then you can play.
When you eat your vegetables, then you can have dessert.

page.introduction: The consequence can also be presented before the condition, in which case there is no marker on the consequence, only on the condition. English examples include:

EnglishExample.exItem: You can buy that if you have enough money saved.
You can play with your friends after you clean your room.
You can have dessert when you have finished your vegetables.
